repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Kabul Aybak and
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Kabul Aybak and
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project for Afghanistan were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            Grantee performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: it is hard to avoid the impression that the
            project was seen as a means of adding funds to emergency
            power rehabilitation project (EPRP) for rehabilitation
            investments, based on needs identified, feasibility, and
            implementation arrangements prepared earlier. Yet a rigorous
            appraisal of the project on its own merits may have revealed
            its design shortcomings. The proposal to provide for an
            obligation of operation and maintenance of the
            infrastructure rehabilitated under the contracts did not
            prove effective because contractors demobilized and
            enforcement of legal remedies to complete works or correct
            defects now needs to be sought. In countries with a history
            of conflict and poor capacity, consideration should be given
            to relative or incremental indicators, for example the
            number of households connected and metered, and the project
            development objective (PDO) framed around these simpler and
            more easily measured metrics. Some flexibility in design is
            essential, including the early identification of alternative
            activities to finance. Similarly, the inability to travel on
            site should be considered at inception, including by
            exploring alternative options through modern technology. It
            is, important that coordination between Ministry of Energy
            and Water (MEW) and Da Afghanistan Breshna Sherkat (DABS) be
            considered together at project design, especially if it is
            known that further sector development is planned during the
            project's lifetime.

16403698.theme: Conflict prevention and post-conflict reconstruction,Infrastructure services for private sector development
16403698.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Kabul Aybak Mazar-e-Sharif
            Power Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Kabul Aybak
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project for Afghanistan is to help
            provide reliable and quality power to the consumers in the
            target areas of the cities of Kabul, Aybak, and
            Mazar-e-Sharif. Considering that: (i) the project
            development objective remains achievable; (ii) Ministry of
            Energy and Water (MEW) has submitted a work plan for Aybak
            and Mazar-e-Sharif substations and the arrangements for
            completing Mazar-e-Sharif distribution system are realistic;
            (iii) some factors causing implementation delays that were
            outside the control of MEW are now resolved; and (iv) full
            disbursement can be achieved by the revised closing date,
            recommend an extension of the grant closing date from June
            30, 2012 to March 31, 2013.

display_title.display_title:
Afghanistan - Kabul Aybak
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project : restructuring : Main report

15589902.theme: Conflict prevention and post-conflict reconstruction,Infrastructure services for private sector development
15589902.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Kabul, Aybak, and
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Kabul,
            Aybak, and Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project for Afghanistan is
            to help provide reliable and quality power to the consumers
            in the target areas of the cities of Kabul, Aybak, and
            Mazar-e-Sharif. This second extension, bringing the
            cumulative extension period to 30 months, is required to
            provide adequate time to complete the remaining project
            activities and thus allow full completion of the Project
            Development Objective (PDO). The activities have been
            delayed due to several factors, some of which have been
            outside the control of the project implementing entity.

display_title.display_title:
Afghanistan - Kabul, Aybak, and
            Mazar-e-Sharif Power Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
